headline.main: A Town of Guinea Pigs Celebrates Its Contribution to Longer Life

docs.abstract: Framingham Heart Study marks 50th anniversary, and gala party in Framingham, Mass, will honor the people whose faithful submission to all kinds of tests and questionnaires over the years has enabled scientists to greatly increase their understanding of heart disease and to help countless Americans lead longer, healthier lives; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: If all the Americans who owe some of the length or quality of their lives to the Framingham Heart Study were to express their gratitude by attending its 50th anniversary gala on Sunday afternoon, the auditorium would need millions upon millions of folding chairs. ''It would be fair to say that Framingham has arguably contributed more than any other town in the United States to advance the health of our nation,'' said Dr. Daniel Levy, the study's director, who will be at the gala.
docs.snippet: If all the Americans who owe some of the length or quality of their lives to the Framingham Heart Study were to express their gratitude by attending its 50th anniversary gala on Sunday  afternoon, the auditorium would need millions upon millions of...

headline.main: Cause Elusive In Death of Griffith Joyner

docs.abstract: Orange County, Calif, authorities continue performing autopsy to try to determine cause of death of 1988 Olympic sprint champion Florence Griffith Joyner (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Authorities continued performing an autopsy yesterday to try to determine the cause of death of the 1988 Olympic sprint champion, Florence Griffith Joyner, who did not wake from her sleep on Monday morning at her home in Mission Viejo, Calif. Hector Rivera, a spokesman for the Orange County Coroner's Office, said that it was not uncommon for an autopsy to extend into a second day and that toxicology tests are routinely performed in a case of sudden or unknown death. The results of the autopsy may not be known for several days or several weeks, he said.
docs.snippet: Authorities continued performing an autopsy yesterday to try to determine the cause of death of the 1988 Olympic sprint champion, Florence Griffith Joyner, who did not wake from her sleep on Monday morning at her home in Mission Viejo, Calif.   ...

headline.main: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

docs.abstract: Pediatricians and other specialists who work with babies born to crack addicts say that early intervention can fight drug's effect on child; various studies of cocaine-addicted babies throughout country have resulted in contradictory findings; several experts discuss problems with such studies, particularly in regard to factors like environment, mother's life-style and poverty; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: When the first babies were born to crack addicts in the mid-1980's, images of trembling infants with tubes up their noses led to fears that such children were irreversibly damaged and doomed to grow into violent misfits. The dire predictions failed to materialize by the early 1990's, prompting a different conclusion: that cocaine causes no lingering effects on children born to drug-addicted mothers. Instead, it was asserted, whatever problems the children had could be attributed to poverty and other environmental factors.
